/ANNEX F-1: STRENGTHENING AND RATIONALISING OUR RETIREMENT SYSTEM/(A) Increase in Senior Workers’ CPF Contribution Rates/
_node_content:
{"id_": "d3883ad1-8578-47e9-9ba6-dfe7943d2f83", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX F-1: STRENGTHENING AND RATIONALISING OUR RETIREMENT SYSTEM/(A) Increase in Senior Workers’ CPF Contribution Rates/"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "e68b06b4-2dce-458d-a3c7-c6568f54ac82", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "0f35435b93d0489c7e50589caaedf4396a0be373980e517e7769b52e3594d3b0", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "2": {"node_id": "2d5f79a5-a250-48e9-acc6-33882e71afb6", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX F-1: STRENGTHENING AND RATIONALISING OUR RETIREMENT SYSTEM/"}, "hash": "0e5739d4b23c05e9054a81945d785f3e9b41b6ae7d9babf83e8baf0f34e81ac1", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "3c4c3250-aaa8-424c-b07c-6d7a78ed1eae", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX F-1: STRENGTHENING AND RATIONALISING OUR RETIREMENT SYSTEM/(A) Increase in Senior Workers’ CPF Contribution Rates/"}, "hash": "e6cd013f9eb7cbc16f282a9c4f4df0c5abaa8d9fd8f40155165bb8242a0e6c4c", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "### Table 1: Current and Target CPF Contribution Rates (Employer + Employee) by Age Band

| Age Band               | 2016–2021 | Current CPF Contribution Rates (As of 1 January 2024) | By ~2030 |
|-----------------------|-----------|--------------------------------------------------------|----------|
| 55 and below          | 37.0%    | No change                                             |          |
| Above 55 to 60       | 26.0%    | 31.0%                                                | 37.0%    |
| Above 60 to 65       | 16.5%    | 22.0%                                                | 26.0%    |
| Above 65 to 70       | 12.5%    | 16.5%                                                | 16.5%    |
| Above 70             | 12.5%    | No change                                             |          |

> **Note:** The timeline is subject to change, depending on prevailing economic conditions.

The Government has implemented the increase in senior workers’ CPF contribution rates for workers aged above 55 to 70 each year since 1 January 2022. We reached the target contribution rates for senior workers aged above 65 to 70 in 2024.

The next increase in senior workers’ CPF contribution rates for workers aged above 55 to 65 will take place on 1 January 2025, as shown in Table 2. The increase in contribution rates will be fully allocated to the CPF Special Account (“SA”) or Retirement Account (“RA”) to help senior workers save more for retirement.

To mitigate the rise in business costs due to this increase, the Government will provide employers with a one-year CPF Transition Offset equivalent to half of the 2025 increase in employer CPF contribution rates for every Singaporean and Permanent Resident worker they employ aged above 55 to 65 (see Table 2). This will be provided automatically and employers do not need to apply for the offset.", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 1066, "end_char_idx": 2932, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{content}", "metadata_template": "{key}: {value}", "metadata_seperator": "
", "class_name": "TextNode"}

| Age Band               | CPF Contribution Rates from 1 January 2025 | CPF Transition          |
|-----------------------|---------------------------------------------|-------------------------|
|                       | Total                  | Employer              | Employee              | Offset for 2025      |
| 55 and below          | No change             |                       |                       |                     |
| Above 55 to 60       | 32.5%                 | 15.5%                | 17.0%                | 0.25%-pt            |
|                       | (+1.5%-pt)           | (+0.5%-pt)           | (+1%-pt)             |                     |
| Above 60 to 65       | 23.5%                 | 12.0%                | 11.5%                | 0.25%-pt            |
|                       | (+1.5%-pt)           | (+0.5%-pt)           | (+1%-pt)             |                     |
| Above 65 to 70       | No change (target contribution rates were reached in 2024) | | |                     |
| Above 70             | No change             |                       |                       |                     |

**Notes:**
1. The CPF contribution rates are stated as a percentage of wages.
2. The percentage point figures in parentheses refer to the increase in CPF contribution rates from 1 January 2025, compared to current rates as of 1 January 2024.

| Year   | Before Changes (ERS at three times the BRS) | Estimated monthly payouts | Revised ERS from 1 January 2025 (ERS at four times the BRS) | Estimated monthly payouts |
|--------|----------------------------------------------|--------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------|
|        | BRS                  | ERS             |                          |                           | ERS             |                          |
| 2025   | $106,500            | $319,500       | $2,530                   | $426,000                 | $3,330                   |
| 2026   | $110,200            | $330,600       | $2,610                   | $440,800                 | $3,440                   |
| 2027   | $114,100            | $342,300       | $2,690                   | $456,400                 | $3,550                   |

**Notes:**
1. There are no changes to the previously announced BRS and Full Retirement Sum for 2025 to 2027.
2. Estimated monthly payouts are based on the payouts of a male member who sets aside the ERS at age 55 and starts payouts under the CPF LIFE Standard Plan at age 65.

With the raising of the ERS, more members aged 55 and above can opt to fully commit their accumulated CPF savings to receive higher CPF payouts.", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 5345, "end_char_idx": 6706, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

header_path: /Budget Statement For Budget 2024/
_node_content:
{"id_": "352728b4-8ad2-440a-8417-e059c5e892b0", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"header_path": "/Budget Statement For Budget 2024/"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "e68b06b4-2dce-458d-a3c7-c6568f54ac82", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "0f35435b93d0489c7e50589caaedf4396a0be373980e517e7769b52e3594d3b0", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "2": {"node_id": "1b6d2d23-dfde-4885-97f7-33d36fc9617b", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/"}, "hash": "62e33acf292e6564a8e08fbc2441d89be371e4857628aabfd874f5e91597308d", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "ea63818e-ae19-4da1-9ecf-f640e5785865", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/Budget Statement For Budget 2024/"}, "hash": "d8c7b6e3811dd5f3b4df591de4a5ebf4d7fe3a32651b25d1a09a84188ff8b3f9", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "## (C) Closure of the CPF Special Account (“SA”) for Members Aged 55 and Above

Today, members aged 55 and above have two CPF accounts that hold savings intended for retirement payouts: the CPF SA and the Retirement Account (“RA”). Both SA and RA savings earn the same long-term interest rate. However, some SA savings can be withdrawn on demand from age 55. As a principle, only savings that cannot be withdrawn on demand should earn the long-term interest rate, and savings that can be withdrawn on demand should earn the short-term interest rate.

To better align CPF interest rates to the nature of CPF savings in each CPF account, the Government will close the SA for members aged 55 and above from early 2025. SA savings will be transferred to the RA, up to the Full Retirement Sum. These savings will continue to earn the long-term interest rate. Any remaining SA savings will be transferred to the Ordinary Account (“OA”), where they remain withdrawable and will earn the short-term interest rate.

Members can choose to transfer their OA savings to their RA at any time, up to the Enhanced Retirement Sum. Once transferred to the RA, the monies will be committed towards higher retirement payouts and will earn higher interest.

With the closure of the SA for members aged 55 and above, all members will have three CPF accounts at any one time:

- For members below age 55, they will continue to have OA, SA, and MediSave Account (“MA”).
- For members aged 55 and above, they will only have OA, RA, MA.", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 6745, "end_char_idx": 8256, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{content}", "metadata_template": "{key}: {value}", "metadata_seperator": "
", "class_name": "TextNode"}

_node_content:
{"id_": "ea63818e-ae19-4da1-9ecf-f640e5785865", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"header_path": "/Budget Statement For Budget 2024/"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "e68b06b4-2dce-458d-a3c7-c6568f54ac82", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "0f35435b93d0489c7e50589caaedf4396a0be373980e517e7769b52e3594d3b0", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "2": {"node_id": "352728b4-8ad2-440a-8417-e059c5e892b0", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/Budget Statement For Budget 2024/"}, "hash": "6b784adf429b6d3813c34dd9f090e10e7863d2fa1cdd205d3e47183d8df7df4f", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "1c3a0cb3-1def-4c6e-a457-49c3b85d1e66", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/Budget Statement For Budget 2024/(D) Enhancements to the Silver Support Scheme (“SSS”)/"}, "hash": "5172ca476f61e57188ec55d176509cff9d77305d657c79f2bd4216d7925c5e03", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "## (D) Enhancements to the Silver Support Scheme (“SSS”)

The SSS supports Singaporeans aged 65 and above who had low incomes during their working years and have less family support.

The SSS will be enhanced to strengthen support for these seniors. From 1 January 2025:

1. Quarterly payments will be raised by 20% across all payment tiers (see Table 4 below).
2. Criterion for monthly per capita household income will be raised. Singaporeans aged 65 and above with monthly per capita household income of not more than $2,300 and meet all other eligibility criteria will be eligible for the SSS, up from the current criterion of $1,800 (see Table 4 below).", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 8258, "end_char_idx": 8915, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{content}", "metadata_template": "{key}: {value}", "metadata_seperator": "
", "class_name": "TextNode"}

| 5-room        | $360                                                  | $180                                                                     | $430                                                  | $215                                                                     |

**Notes:**
1. Self-employed persons should also have an average annual net trade income of not more than $27,600 when they were aged 45 to 54.
2. Neither senior nor his or her spouse should own a 5-room or larger HDB flat or private property or multiple properties.
3. Senior may live in, but do not own, a 5-room HDB flat.

The enhanced Silver Support Scheme (SSS) will benefit around 290,000 Singaporeans aged 65 and above.

There is no need to apply for the SSS. All Singaporeans aged 65 and above are automatically assessed for eligibility. Those who qualify for the SSS will be notified by the CPF Board. All recipients of the enhanced SSS will receive their first payment in December 2024.

Silver Support payments will continue to supplement the monthly cash assistance provided by the ComCare Long-Term Assistance (LTA) Scheme. All Singaporeans aged 65 and above who are ComCare LTA beneficiaries will receive a Silver Support payment of $430 per quarter. Aside from monthly cash assistance to cover daily living expenses, ComCare LTA beneficiaries receive assistance with their medical bills at public healthcare institutions and free or highly subsidised social services such as home help.", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 9441, "end_char_idx": 12414, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{content}", "metadata_template": "{key}: {value}", "metadata_seperator": "
", "class_name": "TextNode"}

/Table 4: Current and Enhanced Silver Support Quarterly Payments from 1 January 2025/Enhancements to the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS)/
_node_content:
{"id_": "cef29541-6ba9-4e64-a918-dbe37eba988e", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"header_path": "/Table 4: Current and Enhanced Silver Support Quarterly Payments from 1 January 2025/Enhancements to the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS)/"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "e68b06b4-2dce-458d-a3c7-c6568f54ac82", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "0f35435b93d0489c7e50589caaedf4396a0be373980e517e7769b52e3594d3b0", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "2": {"node_id": "abc510ff-4dff-4205-9503-7f7ca5c26a2e", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/Table 4: Current and Enhanced Silver Support Quarterly Payments from 1 January 2025/"}, "hash": "0c59238f34e3e6159687866cd45821b2a3d1e25d51d5425a9f0d780114d06b3f", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "07032a84-0bcd-4078-aea7-5cf8d8f0a904", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/"}, "hash": "a88975c43f5853acbf853db7256e89348bd2962c4f1a4541889352df3bdff7e1", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "### Table 5: Changes to the MRSS from 1 January 2025

| Changes                          | Current                                   | From 1 January 2025                          |
|----------------------------------|-------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|
| Increase in matching grant cap    | $600 per year                            | $2,000 per year, with a $20,000 cap         |
|                                  |                                           | over an eligible member’s lifetime           |
| Removal of age cap               | 55 to 70 years old                       | 55 years old and above                        |
| Removal of tax relief on cash    | Givers are eligible for tax relief on    | Givers are not eligible for tax relief on    |
| top-ups for MRSS-eligible members | cash top-ups they make to MRSS-eligible  | cash top-ups that attract the MRSS matching   |
|                                  | members                                   | grant                                         |

**Note:**
1. There is no change to the other eligibility criteria:
- RA savings below prevailing Basic Retirement Sum. RA savings refer to the cash set aside in the RA (excluding amounts such as interest earned, any government grants received) plus amounts withdrawn such as monthly payouts and lump-sum withdrawals;
- Average monthly income not more than $4,000;
- Owns not more than one property; and
- Annual value of residence is not more than $21,000.

With the enhancements, the number of CPF members eligible for MRSS is expected to increase from 395,000 in 2024 to approximately 800,000 in 2025.

MRSS eligibility is automatically assessed every year. CPF Board will notify eligible members at the beginning of each year and members can also check their eligibility via the CPF website. As long as eligible members receive a cash top-up within the year, they will receive the matching grant the following year.

A member may continue to enjoy tax relief of up to $8,000 per year for cash top-ups he makes to his own SA, RA or MediSave Account, and another $8,000 per year for cash top-ups to such accounts of his loved ones.", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 13604, "end_char_idx": 15816, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{content}", "metadata_template": "{key}: {value}", "metadata_seperator": "
", "class_name": "TextNode"}

/ANNEX I-1: EXAMPLES FOR BUDGET 2024 STATEMENT/
/ANNEX I-1: EXAMPLES FOR BUDGET 2024 STATEMENT/(B) Section D: Equipping Our Workers for Life/
_node_content:
{"id_": "83e430d6-c25c-47f8-8f01-a00092760242", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX I-1: EXAMPLES FOR BUDGET 2024 STATEMENT/(B) Section D: Equipping Our Workers for Life/"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "990d89e4-d6f7-4e0a-9344-39232bea95c4", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "af179ac3e92d3346daaf1b30e2829e55f87edb26c3d74a64336fe3e1ff5e60ae", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "2": {"node_id": "bfe83b2d-98f6-4129-9a52-80c5630a4611", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX I-1: EXAMPLES FOR BUDGET 2024 STATEMENT/"}, "hash": "aeafbd327fdb875eee49f1270ff8bd8f6f29479db39360c087a959bd03879572", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "f46b6ed0-d56c-4df8-9861-517ac2f8b8fb", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX I-1: EXAMPLES FOR BUDGET 2024 STATEMENT/"}, "hash": "3d464ce2cdc21f924c954cebe8190d467168b5881c4f017264d4f32e71e20e39", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "### Mr. Calvin Li Junming

Calvin (age 40) is a Project Director with Khoon Engineering Contractor Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based mechanical and electrical service provider. He has been with the company for over 7 years and manages several electrical engineering projects as the overall project lead.

Calvin believes that continuous training and upskilling can broaden his career opportunities and allow him to contribute widely within the workforce. Having pivoted from the finance to electrical engineering industry, he is not deterred by new challenges and has been receptive to mid-career switches. To enhance career mobility, he has been acquiring a wide range of skillsets, from management-related skills offered by trade associations and tertiary institutions, to technical knowledge from Workforce Singapore's Career Conversion Programme for Sustainability Professionals.

Calvin is continuously looking for new ways to learn and incorporate new skills in his work. He finds the upskilling useful in helping him to add value to the projects that he oversees, like exploring the deployment of more sustainable, energy-efficient equipment, and sourcing for potentially low-carbon emission materials.

According to Calvin, “What you study in school isn’t what you become or where you end up. It’s about your mindset, what’s more important is that you are willing to try. Learning is a never-ending process.”# Budget Statement For Budget 2024", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 1405, "end_char_idx": 2848, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{content}", "metadata_template": "{key}: {value}", "metadata_seperator": "
", "class_name": "TextNode"}

header_path: /ANNEX F-2: MAJULAH PACKAGE/
/ANNEX F-2: MAJULAH PACKAGE/(A) Earn and Save Bonus (“ESB”)/
_node_content:
{"id_": "cc0a7014-8eb0-44b2-a8e4-c2259b2f7a40", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX F-2: MAJULAH PACKAGE/(A) Earn and Save Bonus (“ESB”)/"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "40796cfa-e00e-44d7-a7a2-5fd4de70152c", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "f9680c491c54c9681f11bb6d26f8015c54847a13d6cc9608e524b11351b8a9db", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "2": {"node_id": "bf4d2d66-2d7b-4037-a571-9b2a5a88dabf", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX F-2: MAJULAH PACKAGE/"}, "hash": "f740056433b267a1ace154b114d7f7b2bbeb7b25d0e93ba8eabe912332e520b4", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "35fad43c-1625-4160-92dd-e7435cef2c50", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX F-2: MAJULAH PACKAGE/(A) Earn and Save Bonus (“ESB”)/"}, "hash": "7bc50a0a62c935f37f6a217364e54a6ed312686c4b17fdf6dabdb3e9b6405643", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "### Table 1: Quantum for the ESB

| Average Monthly Income          | Annual Bonus |
|---------------------------------|--------------|
| $500 to $2,500                 | $1,000      |
| Above $2,500 to $3,500         | $700        |
| Above $3,500 to $6,000         | $400        |

**Notes:**
1. Refers to the average monthly income based on the number of months worked in the year.
2. Persons with disabilities, workers who qualify for ComCare Short-to-Medium Term Assistance, and caregivers of care recipients (generally include caregivers residing with care recipients who are medically certified to have permanent moderate to severe disabilities) will qualify for a concessionary ESB of $400/year, even if they earn less than $500/month.
3. Paid to the CPF RA, or the SA if the RA has not been created.## Retirement Savings Bonus (“RSB”)

Singaporeans born in 1973 or earlier will receive the RSB if they meet the following criteria:

1. CPF retirement savings below the 2023 Basic Retirement Sum (“BRS”) of $99,400 as at 31 December 2022;
2. Live in a residence with Annual Value (“AV”) of $25,000 and below as at 31 December 2023; and
3. Own not more than one property as at 31 December 2023.

The RSB will be tiered by their CPF retirement savings (see Table 2 below), and will be credited to their CPF Retirement Account (“RA”) or Special Account (“SA”) in December 2024.", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 1479, "end_char_idx": 2860, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{content}", "metadata_template": "{key}: {value}", "metadata_seperator": "
", "class_name": "TextNode"}

| CPF retirement savings1                                   | Bonus2  |
|----------------------------------------------------------|---------|
| Less than $60,000                                       | $1,500  |
| At least $60,000 but less than $99,400 (2023 BRS)      | $1,000  |

**Notes:**
1. Based on the sum of the RA and CPF LIFE balances, or the sum of Ordinary Account and SA balances if RA has not yet been created.
2. Paid to the RA, or the SA if the RA has not been created.

header_path: /ANNEX F-3: ONE-TIME MEDISAVE BONUS/
_node_content:
{"id_": "c602daaa-3bfa-4621-91a1-4f8bd4bb1192", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX F-3: ONE-TIME MEDISAVE BONUS/"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "1b25bc72-e234-42ff-82f0-d59ecd4d6455", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "975bb556df7b9070ba34e4d9ce920509239b9cd5a5d4988a75c689afb56b7991", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "2": {"node_id": "87f5365e-ddfa-4dc8-bf05-ea15fa66d7d7", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/"}, "hash": "19fea27bb8a7fb6ae0b55828bd9459ce4dfffe4fa80d735898c605cd93c6b640", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "776ec993-a423-4a73-aa54-0f142c34b9ea", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX F-3: ONE-TIME MEDISAVE BONUS/"}, "hash": "8dde95d9aed2e067370d56325c050ebd5dc34dc0384360a5b7b126198c8390ac", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "## Table 1: Bonus Quantum

| Singaporeans born in | AV of residence                | Own not more than 1 property | Own more than 1 property |
|-----------------------|--------------------------------|-------------------------------|---------------------------|
|                       | Not more than $25,000         | $300                          | $200                      |
|                       | More than $25,000             | $200                          | $100                      |
| 1974-1983             |                                |                               |                           |
| 1984-2003             |                                |                               |                           |

About 1.4 million Singaporeans will receive the bonus, which is estimated to cost $0.3 billion in total. Together with the MediSave Bonus under the Majulah Package for older Singaporeans, we will collectively provide support for the healthcare costs of about 3 million Singaporeans.", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 666, "end_char_idx": 1685, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

_node_content:
{"id_": "06922f6d-bd2b-458d-b9dd-82e8a25728a3", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX E-2: COMLINK+ PROGRESS PACKAGES/"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "face341d-5ae9-43fb-b172-54e6ebdaf5f1", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "1b3f66ecb265fa76cb3118cf20ebef52b1a89337e1b9c597d9493c1499770ada", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "2": {"node_id": "9044856c-06de-4760-baf3-447848f8e98f", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/"}, "hash": "46bed9c0be16166db2bc442e70aefca2ff861fe7b6091bb03b2611b0f9a4e4f9", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "0fcd34bc-9831-45d1-8f9d-8229186eef5d", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX E-2: COMLINK+ PROGRESS PACKAGES/Table 1: ComLink+ Progress Packages for Families/"}, "hash": "93353b9e5560df7e756d088ebea69e242317433afbf7fd46633e9b5f295bdd05", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "## Table 1: ComLink+ Progress Packages for Families

| Package | Intent of Package      | Action that Family Must Take                                                                 | Financial Top-Ups that Family will Receive                                                                 |
|---------|------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 1       | Preschool Education     | Ensure child is enrolled in preschool in the year he/she turns 3.                         | One-off $500 top-up to child’s Child Development Account (“CDA”).                                         |
|         |                        | Ensure child attends preschool regularly from ages 3-6.                                   | $200 top-up to child’s CDA for every quarter of good attendance (i.e., ≥75% attendance).                   |
| 2       | Employment              | Secure and sustain a CPF-paying job that pays gross monthly salary of ≥ $1,400.          | Up to two working adults will each receive a combination of cash and CPF payouts amounting to a total of between $450 and $550, for every three consecutive months of employment. If two adults are working, each will receive $50 more per quarter. |
|         |                        |                                                                                             | The total payout across employment and savings packages (i.e., Packages 2 and 4) is capped at $30,000.    |

----

This document outlines the ComLink+ Progress Packages aimed at supporting lower-income families in various aspects of their lives, particularly focusing on education and employment.


| Action that Family Must Take                     | Financial Top-Ups that Family will Receive                                                                 |
|--------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Package 3**                                    | **Intent of Package**                                                                                     |
| Financial Stability                               | To help families build financial resilience and clearing debt.                                            |
|                                                  | 1:1 matched debt repayment – for every $1 that family repays to creditors, donors will pay $1 directly to creditors. Repayments will be matched up to a limit of $5,000 in total debt repaid. Eligible families can only benefit once from this package. |
|                                                  |                                                                                                            |
| **Package 4**                                    | **Intent of Package**                                                                                     |
| Saving for home ownership                         | To help families save up for their flat purchase.                                                         |
|                                                  | 2:1 matched CPF contribution – for every $1 of voluntary CPF contribution that a family makes to their CPF accounts, $2 top-up will be made to the same member’s/members’ CPF Ordinary Accounts. The total payout across employment and savings packages (i.e., Packages 2 and 4) is capped at $30,000. |

**Note:** Packages 1 and 3 will be fully funded by corporate and community donors.", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 1152, "end_char_idx": 4839, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{content}", "metadata_template": "{key}: {value}", "metadata_seperator": "
", "class_name": "TextNode"}

| Age Band               | Before Enhancement (For Work Done from 1 Jan 2023 to 31 Dec 2024) | After Enhancement (For Work Done from 1 Jan 2025) |
|-----------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------|
| 30-34                 | $2,100                                                              | $2,450                                            |
| 35-44                 | $3,000                                                              | $3,500                                            |
| 45-59                 | $3,600                                                              | $4,200                                            |
| 60 & above            | $4,200                                                              | $4,900                                            |
| All persons with disabilities | $4,200                                                      | $4,900                                            |

> **Note:** In addition, the worker must earn an average gross monthly wage of not more than **$3,000** in the past 12 months.## Budget Statement for Budget 2024", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 1690, "end_char_idx": 2948, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

header_path: /ANNEX E-1: UPLIFTING LOWER-WAGE WORKERS/(A) Enhancements to the Workfare Income Supplement Scheme (“Workfare”)/
_node_content:
{"id_": "720488a5-d1ca-4111-bff1-8e04132a3e8f", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX E-1: UPLIFTING LOWER-WAGE WORKERS/(A) Enhancements to the Workfare Income Supplement Scheme (“Workfare”)/"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "9a15a971-50a1-4e6d-90d0-7efdd6700471", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "6f469eaf38e2d273bfd28f30c9822731e4c19ecb873c63aecc5bb0cf8dec87bb", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "2": {"node_id": "95e65411-fd0a-4b93-97de-8fb331608955", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX E-1: UPLIFTING LOWER-WAGE WORKERS/(A) Enhancements to the Workfare Income Supplement Scheme (“Workfare”)/"}, "hash": "9e76baf0f17ac6b024b5c5b9f2b266667db437e335fad5675891d36ed92a58ed", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "f4e1d997-cb32-4101-b84b-989634645363", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX E-1: UPLIFTING LOWER-WAGE WORKERS/(A) Enhancements to the Workfare Income Supplement Scheme (“Workfare”)/"}, "hash": "4db0d95914ec3fa8016e7f3fdd69d0338f4816fda74116693df2db16d2a97593", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "### (B) Raising the Local Qualifying Salary (“LQS”)

As part of our Progressive Wages moves, firms hiring foreign workers are required to pay all their local workers at least the LQS. The number of local workers paid the LQS is used to determine the firm’s foreign worker quota entitlement.

The LQS is regularly reviewed to keep pace with wage growth, to continue to uplift lower-wage workers and maintain foreign workforce controls.

The Government will raise the LQS from **$1,400** to **$1,600** per month. Firms hiring foreign workers will have to pay all their local workers at least the LQS (or Progressive Wage Model wages where applicable):

- (i) At least **$1,600** per month for full-time local workers; or
- (ii) At least **$10.50** per hour for part-time local workers.

Foreign worker quota computation will correspondingly be adjusted with the new LQS:

- (i) **1 local workforce count**: Per local worker who is paid at least **$1,600** per month;
- (ii) **0.5 local workforce count**: Per local worker who is paid at least **$800** but less than **$1,600** per month.

These changes will be implemented from **1 July 2024**.", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 2950, "end_char_idx": 4092, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{content}", "metadata_template": "{key}: {value}", "metadata_seperator": "
", "class_name": "TextNode"}

{"id_": "587caa04-dc29-489d-8e77-d8449150bf18", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"header_path": "/"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "13960a20-0fad-477c-8631-b5a81e3f3119", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "9d07034250383ca32c8ae0a406cf5057649afad72b6d7f6e10d59a08a8560acb", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "c7e8a5f1-57bb-4896-ace9-5e95cb65ce32", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX D-1: SKILLSFUTURE LEVEL-UP PROGRAMME/"}, "hash": "4858876843c8fae772f77184152117a443cff0415a4c71a183318b3a3051e0e3", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "# ANNEX D-1: SKILLSFUTURE LEVEL-UP PROGRAMME

The SkillsFuture Level-Up Programme seeks to support mid-career Singaporeans aged 40 and above in undertaking significant reskilling and upskilling to boost their prospects in their current job or pivot to a new career. It comprises three new measures:

| Measure | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| (A)     | $4,000 SkillsFuture Credit (Mid-Career) Top-Up |
| (B)     | Support for mid-career Singaporeans to pursue another subsidised full-time Diploma |
| (C)     | SkillsFuture Mid-Career Training Allowance |", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 0, "end_char_idx": 566, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{content}", "metadata_template": "{key}: {value}", "metadata_seperator": "
", "class_name": "TextNode"}

{"id_": "df720d34-e9d4-4324-8d40-fd324b63c49f", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX D-1: SKILLSFUTURE LEVEL-UP PROGRAMME/"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "13960a20-0fad-477c-8631-b5a81e3f3119", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "9d07034250383ca32c8ae0a406cf5057649afad72b6d7f6e10d59a08a8560acb", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "2": {"node_id": "f9f3558b-5a30-457d-8d14-fc3db3316160", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX D-1: SKILLSFUTURE LEVEL-UP PROGRAMME/"}, "hash": "114002584c85cddfc7284c8ce2dda461ee328c2a6d16ece73fa228b15a755bc7", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "39e88bd8-6b5e-4766-95bf-da79e025e237", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX D-1: SKILLSFUTURE LEVEL-UP PROGRAMME/"}, "hash": "0b66a7786125daa82a5496880d9c8f62b63125e170c042446e840dbbf6d8426d", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "## (C) SkillsFuture Mid-Career Training Allowance

To better support mid-career workers who need to undergo substantive reskilling, we will provide a training allowance to Singaporeans aged 40 and above who undertake full-time long-form training, to partially offset the income loss from taking time off from work. This will be made available from early 2025, for eligible individuals who enrol in the following full-time long-form training programmes:

| Programme Type | Description |
|----------------|-------------|
| (i)            | Full-time SkillsFuture Career Transition Programme courses, which are designed to support mid-career transitions into sectors with good hiring opportunities |
| (ii)           | Full-time publicly-funded full qualifications up to undergraduate degree level offered by our Institutes of Higher Learning and Arts Institutions |

----

**MINISTRY OF FINANCE**# Budget Statement For Budget 2024", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 1918, "end_char_idx": 2847, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{content}", "metadata_template": "{key}: {value}", "metadata_seperator": "
", "class_name": "TextNode"}

{"id_": "6ffadd18-9599-414c-a0a6-3f416b0c3b5d", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"header_path": "/"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "3b443c28-cfb3-4892-aaaa-ed17393e2ef7", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "d503b2614b6e820c378f6d5e00abe45839537643d09e96140729f992f4b63fc8", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "d732ae0f-dbbf-4fc6-9b32-4620a8595358", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX C-2: ENERGY EFFICIENCY GRANT/"}, "hash": "efedd82ad10a2cf74f7e9ddb50e3969f0b4b44d30737bc2004047ef82478dae7", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "# ANNEX C-2: ENERGY EFFICIENCY GRANT

The Energy Efficiency Grant (“EEG”) aims to support businesses in their sustainability journey by co-funding investments in energy-efficient (“EE”) equipment.

Launched in 2022 initially for companies in the Food Services, Food Manufacturing, and Retail sectors, the EEG will be expanded to more sectors, including Manufacturing, Construction, Maritime, and Data Centres and their users. Existing grant schemes for the adoption of EE equipment will also be gradually streamlined and subsumed under the EEG.

The EEG GoBusiness webpage will be updated on 1 April 2024 to launch the shopfront for the Manufacturing (including Food Manufacturing), Food Services, and Retail sectors, and will fold in NEA’s Energy Efficiency Fund. The other sectors will be progressively onboarded and companies in all supported sectors can apply for the EEG through the Business Grants Portal by the end of 2024.

Companies registered and operating in Singapore with (i) at least 30% local shareholding, (ii) at least one local employee, and (iii) group annual sales turnover of no more than $500 million will be eligible for support under the EEG.

The EEG will also be enhanced to provide two tiers of support – a Base Tier to provide support for pre-approved EE equipment up to a $30,000 cap; and an Advanced Tier to support companies that wish to make larger investments to drive greater energy efficiency (see Table 1).", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 3, "end_char_idx": 1445, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{content}", "metadata_template": "{key}: {value}", "metadata_seperator": "
", "class_name": "TextNode"}

{"id_": "d732ae0f-dbbf-4fc6-9b32-4620a8595358", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX C-2: ENERGY EFFICIENCY GRANT/"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "3b443c28-cfb3-4892-aaaa-ed17393e2ef7", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "d503b2614b6e820c378f6d5e00abe45839537643d09e96140729f992f4b63fc8", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "2": {"node_id": "6ffadd18-9599-414c-a0a6-3f416b0c3b5d", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/"}, "hash": "6d9652677c388f37daa8782c586824fd513fd6309ab31d436e9dc3848148223f", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "40eab9aa-4421-4468-b555-d5d1a75b52e8", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX C-2: ENERGY EFFICIENCY GRANT/"}, "hash": "38a9ea63e13e815587e2b00ca5bd36ec13d11369cdf7cb6aab0683573133f716", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "## Table 1: Summary of EEG Tiers of Support

| Tier          | Support Cap                 | Qualifying Equipment         | Support Rate (until 31 Mar 2026)                                                                 |
|---------------|-----------------------------|------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Base Tier     | Up to $30,000              | Pre-approved EE equipment    | Government will support 70% and 30% of pre-approved EE equipment costs for SMEs and non-SMEs respectively. |
| Advanced Tier  | Up to $350,000             | EE equipment need not be pre-approved, but must demonstrate energy savings above 350t lifetime carbon abatement | Grant quantum computed based on the lower of: (i) Support levels under the Base Tier; or (ii) EE equipment’s expected lifetime carbon abatement. |

More details will be provided at the MTI Committee of Supply.", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 1447, "end_char_idx": 2408, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{content}", "metadata_template": "{key}: {value}", "metadata_seperator": "
", "class_name": "TextNode"}

{"id_": "63f30828-afb3-4d3a-ba20-f2c39bbc1e3d", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"header_path": "/"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "510e8633-7372-4daf-b6f2-1ab563701af9", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "abf5bc444680b1d9a0bf9c4a44d8c91a64baa41ce56cfc2220994c4b50c76145", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "46dd2f1b-dc2f-4c9a-be0f-8c10b7bf086a", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX B-1: ASSURANCE PACKAGE ENHANCEMENTS/"}, "hash": "146aef9d50a4ff6df978b6953d9dcc5b77638147df2c0d7be2ac96bb2c8a173e", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "# ANNEX B-1: ASSURANCE PACKAGE ENHANCEMENTS

The Government will enhance the Assurance Package (“AP”) further to provide more support to help Singaporeans cope with cost-of-living concerns and economic uncertainties. The enhancements made in Budget 2024 will cost $1.9 billion.

This Annex elaborates on the following:

- (A) Enhancements to the AP; and
- (B) Illustration of Support for Households from the GST Voucher (“GSTV”) Scheme and the AP, including B2024 AP Enhancements.", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 0, "end_char_idx": 480, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

| Disbursement Month | CDC Vouchers per Singaporean Household |
|--------------------|----------------------------------------|
| Jun 2024           | $300                                   |
| Jan 2025           | $300                                   |
| **Total**          | **$600**                               |

**Note:**
1. The CDC Vouchers disbursed in end-June 2024 and January 2025 will expire in end-December 2024 and end-December 2025, respectively.# B2024 Cost-of-Living (“COL”) Special Payment

Eligible Singaporeans who meet the following criteria will receive a one-off cash payment in September 2024:

1. Aged 21 and above in 2024
2. Residing in Singapore
3. Do not own more than one property
4. With Assessable Income of up to $100,000

The B2024 COL Special Payment will benefit about 2.5 million adult Singaporeans.", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 1028, "end_char_idx": 1893, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

1. Eligible adult Singaporeans must be residing in Singapore.
2. Assessable Income will be based on Year of Assessment (YA) 2023, i.e., income earned in 2022.# Budget 2024 COL U-Save

Eligible Singaporean households living in HDB flats and whose household members do not own more than one property will receive a one-off B2024 COL U-Save to help offset their regular utilities expenses. This B2024 COL U-Save will be disbursed in April 2024, July 2024, October 2024, and January 2025. In total, eligible HDB households will receive 2.5 times the amount of regular GSTV – U-Save, or up to $950, in Financial Year (“FY”) 2024.

The B2024 COL U-Save will benefit more than 950,000 Singaporean households.", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 2608, "end_char_idx": 3320, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{"id_": "27131733-2761-48bf-8171-6ca56cb309c0", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"header_path": "/"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "75d113c3-42ac-4aec-8a0c-78bca87f6ae6", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "17defffa69386a7e10399e60081f2580733b38607cb3b92a20fbf1198cce00e7", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "838f58d4-f3d5-44b1-83d8-fe40683c89f1", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX G-2: OVERSEAS HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE TAX DEDUCTION SCHEME/"}, "hash": "bd5afb11068549885cf5e3f2f76034f360a12eea0fa6131bb474ac32eaf0a9c6", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "# ANNEX G-2: OVERSEAS HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE TAX DEDUCTION SCHEME

An Overseas Humanitarian Assistance Tax Deduction Scheme (“OHAS”) will be piloted for four years from **1 January 2025 to 31 December 2028**.

The OHAS will provide individual and corporate donors with **100% tax deduction** for qualifying overseas cash donations. Qualifying overseas cash donations must meet the following two conditions to be eligible for tax deductions:

1. **Donation must be made through a designated charity.**
- Designated charities should have emergency humanitarian assistance as part of their charitable objectives, as well as enhanced governance and controls against illicit fund flows. Charities that qualify will be invited to participate in the pilot. The list of designated charities will be made available from **1 January 2025**.

2. **Donation must be made towards a fund-raiser for emergency humanitarian assistance** with a valid Fund-Raising for Foreign Charitable Purposes (“FRFCP”) permit from the Commissioner of Charities (“COC”).
- Designated charities are required to apply for a FRFCP permit from the COC prior to commencement of a fund-raising appeal for an emergency humanitarian assistance cause.

The COC will determine upon reviewing the FRFCP permit application whether a fund-raiser in question is for an emergency humanitarian assistance cause. Emergency humanitarian assistance refers to emergency assistance tied to a specific incident with a clear trigger such as in response to natural disasters (e.g., earthquakes or floods) or other sudden crises (e.g., pandemics). Assistance typically includes rapid delivery of essentials such as food, clean water, shelter, medical care, and search, rescue, and evacuation efforts.

Tax deductions under OHAS will be capped at **40% of the donor’s statutory income**. For donors who also receive tax deductions under the Philanthropy Tax Incentive Scheme for Family Offices (“PTIS”), tax deductions under both OHAS and PTIS will be jointly capped at **40% of the donor’s statutory income**.

Any unutilised tax deductions under the OHAS cannot be carried forward to offset the donor’s income for any subsequent Year of Assessment (“YA”) and cannot be transferred to another company of the same group under the Group Relief System for any YA.

1. Notwithstanding these charities’ ability to carry out emergency humanitarian assistance overseas, these charities must still substantially benefit the community in Singapore.
2. The PTIS provides qualifying donors **100% tax deduction** for overseas cash donations made through qualifying local intermediaries, capped at **40% of the donor’s statutory income**. To qualify, donors must have a fund under Section 13O or 13U of the Income Tax Act 1947 and meet eligibility conditions, such as incremental local business spending of **S$200,000**. Please visit [MAS Philanthropy Tax Incentive Scheme](www.mas.gov.sg/schemes-and-initiatives/philanthropy-tax-incentive-scheme-for-family-offices) for more information.

----

**MINISTRY OF FINANCE**# Budget Statement For Budget 2024", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 0, "end_char_idx": 3087, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

", "class_name": "TextNode"}

header_path: /ANNEX H-1: TAX CHANGES/
/ANNEX H-1: TAX CHANGES/(A) Tax Changes for Businesses/
/ANNEX H-1: TAX CHANGES/(A) Tax Changes for Businesses/
_node_content:
{"id_": "2d5a5cba-c518-4cc3-9d8e-32076a2d4754", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX H-1: TAX CHANGES/(A) Tax Changes for Businesses/"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "db27da62-6f6d-47e0-a8e0-6fd20e443d25", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "e267f5992cc19511e65749403288a0dcd81c1b9c0f81acb93b4725ef78c39260", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "2": {"node_id": "7070e505-1bf7-417c-a469-5028bf7114dc", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX H-1: TAX CHANGES/(A) Tax Changes for Businesses/"}, "hash": "b3bc317eecd1699476bbec4a8aa32f4f0d4daba5159bf526cbc633805477240e", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "951edfa2-d404-4958-84c7-cd0388d6979b", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX H-1: TAX CHANGES/"}, "hash": "eaec7f52d326e83c55e4fe305b8c7bbdf994c381554d755088505399f89b037e", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "### New Tax Treatment
To help companies manage rising costs, a CIT Rebate of 50% of tax payable will be granted for YA 2024.

Companies that have employed at least one local employee in 2023 (referred to as “local employee condition”) will receive a minimum benefit of $2,000 in the form of a cash payout (referred to as “CIT Rebate Cash Grant”).

Companies that have met the local employee condition will automatically receive the CIT Rebate Cash Grant by 3Q 2024. The CIT Rebate, less any CIT Rebate Cash Grant received, will be automatically incorporated in companies’ tax assessments raised after they file their CIT returns for YA 2024.

For example, Company A hired two local employees in 2023. It has a CIT assessment of $30,000 for YA 2024. Company A will receive a $2,000 CIT Rebate Cash Grant by 3Q 2024. It will receive another $13,000 [(50% * $30,000) - $2,000] in CIT Rebate in its YA 2024 CIT assessment.

The maximum total benefits of CIT Rebate and CIT Rebate Cash Grant that a company may receive is $40,000.

----

**MINISTRY OF FINANCE**



| S/N | Name of Tax Change                          | Existing Tax Treatment                                                                 | New Tax Treatment                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
|-----|--------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 1   |                                            | A company is considered to have met the local employee condition if it has made CPF contributions to at least one local (i.e., Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident) employee, excluding shareholders who are also directors of the company, in the calendar year 2023. |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      |
| 2   | Enhance the tax deduction for Renovation   | Under section 14N of the Income Tax Act (“ITA”), businesses that incur qualifying R&R expenditure may claim a tax deduction on such expenditure over three consecutive YAs on a straight-line basis, starting from the YA relating to the basis period in which the R&R expenditure was incurred. A deduction cap of $300,000 on qualifying R&R expenditure applies every three years, starting from the YA in which businesses make their first claim. | To ease businesses’ compliance burden and improve the relevance of the scheme, MOF will introduce the following enhancements from YA 2025:
a) Expand the scope of qualifying expenditure to include designer or professional fees;
b) Fix the relevant three-year period for the purpose of computing the R&R expenditure cap, with the first three-year period being from YA 2025 to YA 2027. We will transition all businesses to the fixed relevant three-year period; and
c) Allow an option to claim R&R deductions in one YA, subject to the prevailing expenditure cap.
IRAS will provide further details by 3Q 2024. |
| 3   | Introduce the Refundable Investment Credit  | N/A                                                                                    | To enhance Singapore’s attractiveness for investments, we will introduce the RIC, which will support up to 50% of qualifying expenditures. The credits are to be offset against CIT payable. Any unutilised tax credits will be refunded to                                                                                                                                                       |



| S/N | Name of Tax Change                                      | Existing Tax Treatment                                                                 | New Tax Treatment                                                                 |
|-----|-------------------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 4   | Implement the Income Inclusion Rule (“IIR”) and a     | N/A                                                                                    | Singapore will implement the IIR and a DTT, which will impose a minimum         |
|     | Domestic Top-up Tax (“DTT”) under Pillar Two of the   |                                                                                        | effective tax rate of 15% on businesses’ profits from financial years starting   |
|     | Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (“BEPS”) 2.0        |                                                                                        | on or after 1 January 2025. This will apply to relevant multinational enterprise  |
|     |                                                       |                                                                                        | (“MNE”) groups with annual group revenue of 750 million euros or more in at     |
|     |                                                       |                                                                                        | least two of the four preceding financial years (referred to as “in-scope MNE   |
|     |                                                       |                                                                                        | groups”), in line with the Pillar Two Global Anti-Base Erosion (“GloBE”) Model  |
|     |                                                       |                                                                                        | Rules. The IIR will apply to in-scope MNE groups that are parented in Singapore, |
|     |                                                       |                                                                                        | in respect of the profits of their group entities that are operating outside      |
|     |                                                       |                                                                                        | Singapore. The DTT will apply to in-scope MNE groups in respect of the profits   |
|     |                                                       |                                                                                        | of their group entities that are operating in Singapore.                         |
| 5   | Extend and revise the tax incentive schemes for funds  | Under sections 13D, 13O and 13U of the ITA, Qualifying Funds are granted the        | To continue to grow Singapore’s asset and wealth management industry, the        |
|     | managed by Singapore-based fund managers               | following tax concessions, subject to conditions:                                     | schemes will be extended till 31 December 2029. In addition, the following key   |
|     | (referred to as “Qualifying Funds”)                   |                                                                                        | changes will be made:                                                            |



| S/N | Name of Tax Change                                                                 | Existing Tax Treatment                                                                                                                                                                                                 | New Tax Treatment                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
|-----|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|     |                                                                                    | a) Tax exemption on specified income derived from designated investments;                                                                                                                                           | a) The section 13O scheme will be enhanced to include Limited Partnerships registered in Singapore;                                                                                                            |
|     |                                                                                    | b) Withholding tax exemption on interest and other qualifying payments made to non-resident persons (excluding permanent establishments in Singapore);                                                                  | b) The economic criteria for Qualifying Funds under the sections 13D, 13O and 13U schemes will be revised.                                                                                                      |
|     |                                                                                    | c) GST remission on relevant expenses incurred.                                                                                                                                                                      | These key changes will take effect from 1 January 2025. MAS will provide further details by 3Q 2024.                                                                                                           |
|     |                                                                                    |                                                                                                                                                                                                                        | The schemes are scheduled to lapse after 31 December 2024.                                                                                                                                                      |
| 6   | Introduce an alternative basis of tax where the qualifying income of shipping entities will be taxed by reference to net tonnage, for the following Maritime Sector Incentive (“MSI”) sub-schemes: | Under the relevant MSI sub-schemes, qualifying income are exempted from tax.                                                                                                                                         | To better align our tax regime for shipping entities with common international practices, an alternative basis of tax where the qualifying income of qualifying shipping entities is taxed by reference to the net tonnage of their ships will be available under the MSI-SRS, MSI-AIS, and MSI-ML(Ship) from YA 2024. |
|     |                                                                                    |                                                                                                                                                                                                                        | The alternative basis of tax will apply to all qualifying ships of MSI entities that are subjected to it.                                                                                                        |
|     |                                                                                    |                                                                                                                                                                                                                        | The existing tax treatment under the relevant MSI sub-schemes will continue to apply to MSI entities that are not under the alternative net tonnage basis of tax. MPA will provide further details by 3Q 2024.     |



| S/N | Name of Tax Change                                      | Existing Tax Treatment                                                                 | New Tax Treatment                                                                                     |
|-----|-------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 7   | Introduce an additional concessionary tax rate        | Under the FTC incentive, approved companies are eligible for a CTR of 8% on qualifying income. | As part of our periodic review to ensure that our tax incentives remain relevant and competitive, an additional CTR tier of 10% will be introduced under the FTC incentive with effect from 17 February 2024. EDB will provide further details by 2Q 2024. |
| 8   | Introduce an additional CTR tier of 10% for the Aircraft Leasing Scheme (“ALS”) | Under the ALS, approved aircraft lessors are eligible for a CTR of 8% on qualifying income. | As part of our periodic review to ensure that our tax incentives remain relevant and competitive, an additional CTR tier of 10% will be introduced under the ALS for approved aircraft lessors with effect from 17 February 2024. EDB will provide further details by 2Q 2024. |
| 9   | Introduce an additional CTR tier of 15% for the Development and Expansion Incentive (“DEI”) | Under the DEI, approved companies are eligible for CTRs of 5% or 10% on qualifying income. | As part of our periodic review to ensure that our tax incentives remain relevant and competitive, an additional CTR tier of 15% will be introduced under the DEI with effect from 17 February 2024. EDB will provide further details by 2Q 2024. |
| 10  | Introduce an additional CTR tier of 15% for the Intellectual Property Development Incentive (“IDI”) | Under the IDI, approved companies are eligible for CTRs of 5% or 10% on qualifying income. | As part of our periodic review to ensure that our tax incentives remain relevant and competitive, an additional CTR tier of 15% will be introduced under the IDI with effect from 17 February 2024. |



| S/N | Name of Tax Change                                           | Existing Tax Treatment                                                                 | New Tax Treatment                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
|-----|------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 11  | Introduce an additional CTR tier of 15% for the Global     | Under the GTP, approved companies are eligible for CTRs of 5% or 10% on qualifying income. | As part of our periodic review to ensure that our tax incentives remain relevant and competitive, an additional CTR tier of 15% will be introduced under the GTP with effect from 17 February 2024. EDB will provide further details by 2Q 2024. |
|     | Trader Programme (“GTP”)                                   |                                                                                       |                                                                                                                                                                                                                   |
| 12  | Revisions to Additional Buyer’s Stamp Duty (“ABSD”)       | Currently, HDs that purchase residential land are subject to 40% ABSD, comprising a (i) 5% non-remittable component; and (ii) 35% upfront remittable component. | To ensure that the housing supply is released promptly while providing some flexibility for HDs to address the difficulties they may face in selling all units within the prescribed timelines, with effect from 16 February 2024, projects with at least 90% of units sold at the five-year sale timeline will be subjected to a lower ABSD remission clawback rate, if the commencement and completion of works criteria are also fulfilled. This applies for projects where the residential land was acquired on or after 6 July 2018. The ABSD remission clawed back will be reduced by 1 percentage point to 10 percentage points, depending on the proportion of units sold at the five-year mark. |
|     | remission clawback rates for housing developers (“HDs”)    | If a licensed HD that develops five or more residential units fails to sell all their residential units within five years from the date of acquisition of the residential land, the 35% remittable component will be clawed back with interest, regardless of the number of unsold units. |                                                                                                                                                                                                                   |
|     |                                                            | 1 The 40% ABSD (HD) rate applies to purchases of residential land on or after 16 December 2021. For purchases made between 6 July 2018 and 15 December 2021, the applicable ABSD (HD) rate is 30%, comprising a (i) 5% non-remittable component; and (ii) 25% upfront remittable component. |                                                                                                                                                                                                                   |", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 449, "end_char_idx": 19004, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{"id_": "951edfa2-d404-4958-84c7-cd0388d6979b", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX H-1: TAX CHANGES/"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "db27da62-6f6d-47e0-a8e0-6fd20e443d25", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "e267f5992cc19511e65749403288a0dcd81c1b9c0f81acb93b4725ef78c39260", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "2": {"node_id": "2d5a5cba-c518-4cc3-9d8e-32076a2d4754", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/ANNEX H-1: TAX CHANGES/(A) Tax Changes for Businesses/"}, "hash": "b5d8dbe5b01cfe053b97afac7a1eb92faad2f4de83a7e90e23a2ee83d155c956", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "cb90a471-d901-4320-b59a-7bd1c3a50e4c", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"header_path": "/"}, "hash": "62e33acf292e6564a8e08fbc2441d89be371e4857628aabfd874f5e91597308d", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "## (B) Tax Changes for Individuals

| S/N | Name of Tax Change                                                                 |
|-----|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 1   | Personal Income Tax (“PIT”) Rebate for YA 2024                                   |
|     | **Existing Tax Treatment**                                                          |
|     | Providing Support for Individuals                                                   |
|     | In view of cost-of-living concerns, a PIT Rebate of 50% of tax payable will be    |
|     | granted to all tax resident individuals for YA 2024. The rebate will be capped at  |
|     | $200 per taxpayer.                                                                 |
| 2   | Raise dependant’s or caregiver’s income threshold for dependant-related reliefs to $8,000 |
|     | **Existing Tax Treatment**                                                          |
|     | Currently, the annual income of the dependant or caregiver cannot exceed $4,000 in |
|     | the preceding year if a tax-resident individual wishes to claim the following      |
|     | dependant-related reliefs:                                                          |
|     | a) Spouse Relief;                                                                  |
|     | b) Parent Relief;                                                                  |
|     | c) Qualifying Child Relief;                                                         |
|     | d) Working Mother’s Child Relief;                                                  |
|     | e) CPF Cash Top-up Relief for top-up to the siblings;                             |
|     | f) Grandparent Caregiver Relief.                                                   |
|     | **New Tax Treatment**                                                               |
|     | To allow more taxpayers who are providing for dependant family members to enjoy    |
|     | these reliefs, while giving family members the flexibility to do some work, the    |
|     | income threshold of $4,000 will be increased to $8,000 with effect from YA 2025.  |
| 3   | Revision of Annual Value (“AV”) bands for owner-occupier residential Property Tax (“PT”) rates |
|     | **Existing Tax Treatment**                                                          |
|     | Owner-occupied residential properties are taxed by applying the applicable marginal  |
|     | tax rate on the portion of the property’s AV.                                     |
|     | **New Tax Treatment**                                                               |
|     | In view of the sharp rise in AVs over the last two years, the AV bands of the     |
|     | owner-occupier residential PT rates will be adjusted as follows from 1 January 2025: |", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 19008, "end_char_idx": 21857, "text_template": "{metadata_str}
